awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Intersection of Labor and Race in Intercultural Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the goals of historical social scientific research in the United States is to understand the complex interactions between immigrant and host communities and how they differ across space, time, ethnicity, and point-of-origin. Much of recent literature highlights how various forms of discrimination - based on perceived class, gender, or racial/ethnic distinctions - impact immigrants, and how they in turn grapple with these issues and adapt to United States society. How are different immigrant groups, from different origins, affected by the inequality and discrimination they encounter in the United States? How do they respond, in ways that secure their own social and economic needs? How has this changed over time? Archaeology is well equipped to help answer these questions. The archaeological record is not necessarily subject to the same kinds of biases as archival and oral historical sources. Thus, when combined with these sources, it provides a more complete picture of community responses to inequality and discrimination. Because the archeological record is often formed from the daily, practical, and habitual actions of human beings, archaeology is particularly well-equipped to push beyond investigations of conscious political action (such as activism and civil lawsuits) and understand how the dynamic relationships between immigrant and host communities influenced immigrants' daily lives. In addition to the research it will conduct this project will also employ and train undergraduate and graduate students in the methods of archaeological survey and excavation, and build connections with local community institutions, both as part of public outreach and as a foundation for future collaboration. The project's results will be made available through university-funded data depositories, public talks and site tours, and a thematic website dedicated to issues of Japanese American history, archaeology, and immigration.

This project's Principal Investigators will, with the assistance of paid and volunteer researchers, examine how local labor hierarchies, direct and indirect racism, cultural traditions, and on-the-ground strategies deployed by first-generation Japanese American (Issei) sawmill workers are reflected in and mediated through the material evidence for daily activities. This research will be conducted at the sawmill town of Barneston, Washington (1898-1924). Barneston is an excellent location for such research; it employed a significant proportion of Issei workers and operated during a period of turbulent economic and social changes which may have affected Issei sawmill laborers.  The researchers will use archaeological evidence, supplemented by written and oral histories, to reconstruct a variety of daily activities, including dining and food consumption, drinking, and gaming behavior. The goal is to determine the extent to which Issei at Barneston adopted anti-exclusion behaviors which were proposed by regional Issei leadership as a means of reducing anti-Japanese hysteria, and how such adoption varied throughout the community. In doing so, this project will add to archaeology's collective knowledge of the intersection of labor, race, and culture.

por.por_cntn:
David Carlson has completed research for his dissertation “Residence, Resistance, and Racialization: A Historical Archaeology of Japanese American Daily Life at Barneston, Washington,” supported by an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. During his funding period, Carlson spent 17 weeks conducting archaeological fieldwork at the historic sawmill townsite of Barneston, Washington (1898-1924). As a historical archaeologist, Carlson was interested in understanding what the archaeological record at Barneston could tell us about the lives of Japanese immigrants and Japanese Americans. In particular, he wanted to know what kinds of choices and strategies they made in order to build lives for themselves and meet their own cultural, social, and psychological needs in response to the anti-Japanese racism and labor inequality that was common at the time.

Several elements of Carlson’s research were funded by the NSF grant. The largest of these was the fieldwork. With the assistance of a little over two dozen student volunteers, Carlson surveyed the old Japanese community at Barneston, mapping in surface features like water pipes, human-made rock piles, pits, and piles of bricks and other debris. Once the survey was complete, he homed in on a few key areas that he hoped would speak more about this community. One area was the former location of a residence, where bachelors—and perhaps, families—once lived. Another was a communal bathhouse, a site of much cultural activity for Barneston’s Japanese workers. Finally, he also investigated an anomalous pit feature that he thought might have some information about what people in the community ate. Once the fieldwork was completed, the artifacts that Carlson and his crew found were taken to the Pacific Northwestern Archaeology Lab at the University of Washington to be analyzed. There, glass bottles, ceramic fragments, bone and plant remains, and many other types of material culture were catalogued and analyzed by Carlson and another group of student volunteers. Between the fieldwork and labwork, the NSF grant gave Carlson the opportunity to provide training and experience in archaeological methods to a little over two dozen undergraduate and graduate students.

In addition, the NSF grant paid for specialized analysis. An ethnobotanist—someone who studies how people make use of native and indigenous plants—was contracted to analyze plant remains recovered from soil samples taken at the site. Furthermore, Carlson and a hired student worker skimmed some Japanese language newspapers from the early 1900s. They identified a set of key articles which were then sent to a professional translator. These documents will prove very useful for interpreting the archaeology at the site. One, for example, speaks to the reasons for why Japanese communities were often segregated on these sites. It indicates that safety was a concern for Japanese sawmill workers; they felt safer together, where it would be harder for resentful workers to attack them. This is not the only reason for the segregation of Japanese workers, of course. Racism among company owners and non-Japanese workers also occurred. But it does add some nuance to our understanding of the daily lives of the Japanese immigrants who lived at places like Barneston.

The artifact analysis is still ongoing, but already Carlson has been able to draw some interesting conclusions. Data from the bathhouse, for example, shows just how important it was as a communal space. Evidence for drinking, eating, and other activities related to relaxation are present. In addition, there is evidence that the bathhouse was also a place for workers to get their laundry done. This is consistent with the historic uses of bathhouses in Japan and shows how Japanese workers at Barneston worked hard to recreate elements of their culture in the otherwise harsh labor environment of a sawmill town. Once the full analysis is completed, Carlson will be able to compare the material at the bathhouse with that from other areas of the site and begin to understand how workers at Barneston sustained themselves and met their own needs in the context of anti-Japanese racism and labor inequality.
